title: OFDM Transmitter and Receiver – Block Diagram & Explanation
narration: Welcome to this comprehensive guide on Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing or OFDM. In this video we will explore the intricacies of OFDM a cornerstone technology in modern wireless communication.

title: What is OFDM?
content:
Multicarrier modulation technique.
Used in Wi-Fi, LTE, and 5G.
Divides bandwidth into narrowband subcarriers.
Subcarriers are orthogonal to each other.
narration: OFDM or Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing is a multicarrier modulation technique widely used in wireless communication systems. It's the backbone of technologies like WiFi LTE and the latest fifth generation networks. OFDM cleverly divides the available bandwidth into multiple narrowband subcarriers ensuring that these subcarriers are orthogonal to each other which is key to its efficiency.

title: OFDM Transmitter Block Diagram
image_desc: OFDM transmitter block diagram. Type: diagram
narration: Let's delve into the architecture of an OFDM transmitter. This diagram provides a visual representation of the various stages involved in preparing data for transmission using OFDM. Each block plays a crucial role in ensuring efficient and reliable communication.

title: OFDM Transmitter - Serial to Parallel Conversion
content:
Converts serial data stream into parallel streams.
Prepares data for multiple subcarriers.
image_desc: Serial to parallel conversion diagram. Type: illustration
narration: The first step in the OFDM transmitter is serial to parallel conversion. This process takes the incoming serial data stream which is a single stream of bits and converts it into multiple parallel data streams. This conversion is essential to prepare the data for transmission across multiple subcarriers simultaneously.

title: OFDM Transmitter - Modulation (QAM / QPSK)
image_desc: QAM and QPSK modulation schemes. Type: comparison chart
narration: Next each of these parallel data streams undergoes modulation. Modulation is the process of encoding the data onto a carrier signal. Common modulation techniques used in OFDM include Quadrature Amplitude Modulation or QAM and Quadrature Phase Shift Keying or QPSK. The choice of modulation scheme depends on the desired data rate and channel conditions.

title: OFDM Transmitter - Inverse Fast Fourier Transform (IFFT)
content: Converts frequency-domain data to time-domain. Ensures subcarrier orthogonality.
narration: Following modulation the Inverse Fast Fourier Transform or IFFT comes into play. The IFFT converts the modulated data from the frequency domain into the time domain. This transformation is crucial because it ensures that the subcarriers remain orthogonal to each other preventing interference between them.

title: OFDM Transmitter - Add Cyclic Prefix
content:
Adds a copy of the end of the symbol to the beginning.
Prevents Inter-Symbol Interference (ISI).
image_desc: Cyclic prefix insertion diagram. Type: illustration
narration: To mitigate the effects of multipath propagation a cyclic prefix is added to each OFDM symbol. The cyclic prefix is simply a copy of the last part of the OFDM symbol which is appended to the beginning. This technique helps to prevent InterSymbol Interference or ISI which can occur when signals arrive at the receiver at different times due to multiple paths.

title: OFDM Transmitter - Parallel to Serial Conversion & RF Upconversion
content:
**Parallel to Serial Conversion**
Converts parallel data back to serial.
**RF Upconversion**
Converts baseband signal to radio frequency.
image_desc: Parallel to serial conversion and RF upconversion. Type: diagram
narration: After adding the cyclic prefix the parallel data streams are converted back into a single serial stream. Finally the baseband OFDM signal is upconverted to a radio frequency or RF suitable for wireless transmission. This upconversion process shifts the signal to the desired carrier frequency.

title: OFDM Receiver Block Diagram
image_desc: OFDM receiver block diagram. Type: diagram
narration: Now let's shift our focus to the OFDM receiver. This diagram illustrates the various stages involved in recovering the transmitted data from the received signal. Each block in the receiver performs the inverse operation of its counterpart in the transmitter.

title: OFDM Receiver - RF Downconversion & Serial to Parallel Conversion
content:
**RF Downconversion**
Converts RF signal to baseband.
**Serial to Parallel Conversion**
Converts serial data to parallel streams.
image_desc: RF downconversion and serial to parallel conversion. Type: diagram
narration: The first step in the OFDM receiver is RF downconversion. This process converts the received RF signal back to baseband. Following downconversion the serial data stream is converted into multiple parallel streams mirroring the process in the transmitter.

title: OFDM Receiver - Remove Cyclic Prefix & Fast Fourier Transform (FFT)
image_desc: Cyclic prefix removal and FFT process. Type: diagram
narration: Next the cyclic prefix is removed from each OFDM symbol. This step restores the original OFDM symbols without the added prefix. Then the Fast Fourier Transform or FFT is applied to convert the timedomain signal back into the frequency domain allowing the receiver to retrieve the transmitted data symbols.

title: OFDM Receiver - Demodulation & Parallel to Serial Conversion
image_desc: Demodulation and parallel to serial conversion. Type: diagram
narration: The data symbols are then demodulated using the appropriate demodulation technique such as QAM or QPSK. This process extracts the original bit stream from the modulated signal. Finally the parallel data streams are converted back into a single serial bit stream which represents the recovered data.

title: Advantages of OFDM
content:
High Spectral Efficiency
Resistant to Multipath Interference
Low Complexity
Flexible Modulation
narration: OFDM offers several key advantages. It provides high spectral efficiency making efficient use of the available bandwidth. It's also resistant to multipath interference thanks to the cyclic prefix. The use of FFT and IFFT algorithms makes it relatively low in complexity and it supports flexible modulation schemes adapting to varying channel conditions.

title: Conclusion
narration: In conclusion OFDM is a powerful and versatile technique used in modern wireless communication systems. By dividing data into multiple orthogonal subcarriers it improves data transmission reliability and efficiency. The transmitter and receiver processes ensure efficient modulation transmission and demodulation while minimizing interference. Thank you for watching
